content:
My apologies for the error in the calculation. Let's recalculate the heat rate (Q) using the correct values:

I = 1000 A
R = 2.53 x 10^-6 Ω
t = 0.5 s

Q = I^2 \* R \* t
Q = (1000 A)^2 \* 2.53 x 10^-6 Ω \* 0.5 s
Q = 1.265 J

The correct heat rate (Q) is indeed 1.265 Joules.

To convert this heat amount to Watts, we need to divide the heat rate (Q) by the duration (t) in seconds:

W = Q / t
W = 1.265 J / 0.5 s
W = 2.53 Watts

Therefore, the heat amount is equivalent to 2.53 Watts.
